1.title: ARC Is a Vision Problem!
1.summary: This paper reinterprets the Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus (ARC) as a vision-centric challenge, treating it as an image-to-image translation problem. The authors introduce Vision ARC (VARC), leveraging standard vision models, specifically Vision Transformer (ViT), to solve ARC tasks by processing inputs as visual canvases. Trained exclusively on ARC data, VARC achieves 60.4% accuracy on the ARC-1 benchmark, outperforming traditional scratch-trained models and approaching human-level performance. These results suggest vision architectures can compete with or surpass language models on abstract reasoning benchmarks.
key_findings: ARC can be reframed as a vision problem
Vision Transformer models can solve ARC tasks effectively
VARC achieves 60.4% accuracy on ARC-1 benchmark
Performance exceeds other scratch-trained methods
Results competitive with large language models
Approaches average human performance on ARC

2.title: VULPO: Context-Aware Vulnerability Detection via On-Policy LLM Optimization
2.summary: This paper presents VULPO, a novel on-policy reinforcement learning framework using large language models (LLMs) to improve context-aware vulnerability detection in open-source software. The authors introduce ContextVul, a new dataset designed to provide repository-level context alongside function-level vulnerability samples. VULPO incorporates multi-dimensional, difficulty-adaptive reward mechanisms to ensure balanced learning and address the varying challenges of different vulnerability cases. Experiments show that VULPO-4B significantly outperforms existing vulnerability detection baselines and even matches the performance of much larger models.
key_findings: Introduces VULPO, an on-policy RL framework for context-aware vulnerability detection
ContextVul dataset augments method-level data with repository-level context
Uses multi-dimensional, adaptive reward structuring
Addresses sample difficulty to balance learning and reduce reward hacking
VULPO-4B outperforms prompt-engineered and off-policy LLM baselines
Performance rivals models 150 times larger in size

3.title: OG-VLA: Orthographic Image Generation for 3D-Aware Vision-Language Action Model
3.summary: OG-VLA introduces a novel vision-language-action (VLA) architecture that integrates 3D-aware policies and foundation models to enable robust robot manipulation from RGBD and language input. The method unprojects observations into point clouds and renders them into orthographic views, achieving view invariance and aligning input-output spaces. Using a vision backbone, LLM, and image diffusion, OG-VLA predicts precise end-effector poses for manipulation. Experiments on challenging benchmarks show strong generalization to unseen instructions, scenes, and objects, including successful real-world adaptation with minimal demonstrations.
key_findings: Achieves state-of-the-art generalization to unseen environments (40% improvement)
Combines 3D-aware robot policies with VLAs for robust, flexible manipulation
Orthographic image generation provides view invariance and consistency
Success in few-shot real-world adaptation (3–5 demonstrations)
Uses point cloud unprojection and canonical views for alignment
Leverages foundation models (vision, LLM, diffusion) for policy learning

4.title: Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Proximal Policy Optimization for Power Distribution System Restoration
4.summary: This paper introduces Heterogeneous-Agent Proximal Policy Optimization (HAPPO) for coordinating power distribution system (PDS) restoration using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Each agent represents a distinct microgrid with differing operational constraints, enabling realistic modeling of structural heterogeneity. Training employs decentralized policies with a centralized critic in a physics-informed OpenDSS environment that enforces system constraints via differentiable penalties. Experiments on standard benchmark networks demonstrate that HAPPO outperforms several state-of-the-art RL approaches in convergence speed, power restoration levels, and training stability, highlighting scalability and practical applicability for real-world grid restoration.
key_findings: HAPPO effectively models and leverages microgrid heterogeneity
Centralized critic with decentralized actors stabilizes training
Physics-informed OpenDSS environment enforces system constraints
HAPPO outperforms other RL methods in speed and restoration levels
Demonstrates scalability up to IEEE 8500-node test systems
Constraint handling via penalties improves learning dynamics

5.title: Automated proving in planar geometry based on the complex number identity method and elimination
5.summary: This paper presents an automated method for proving geometric theorems in the plane using complex number identities and elimination ideals. The authors convert geometric hypotheses and conclusions into algebraic equations, clear denominators, and eliminate variables to obtain results in rational polynomial ideals. The approach is implemented in Mathematica, Maple, Giac, and an experimental GeoGebra prototype. This work advances fully automated reasoning in planar geometry.
key_findings: Complex number identity method extended to full automation
Relational and point variables eliminated via polynomial ideals
Prototype implementation in dynamic geometry software
Method integrated into leading computer algebra systems
Linear polynomial criterion for conclusive results
